questions.text: A 4 day old baby is active and feeding well. He has a bilirubin level of 8 mg/dl. What is the next step in the management of the baby?
questions.solution:
Since this child has a bilirubin level of only 8 mg/dl on the 4th day, it points to physiologic jaundice. The child is active and feeding well, the mother should be encouraged to continue breastfeeding frequently and exclusively.

All the other options would be possible treatment choices if the child had pathological jaundice. 

Physiological jaundice/Icterus neonatorum is due to increased bilirubin production from the breakdown of fetal red blood cells combined with transient limitation in the conjugation of bilirubin by the immature neonatal liver. It first appears on the 2nd or 3rd days usually peaks on the 4th day at 5-6 mg/dL and decreases to <2 mg/dL between the 5th and 7th days after birth.

On the other hand, in pathological jaundice, appearance is within the first 24 hours after birth and may be present at or beyond the age of 2 weeks in term babies and 3 weeks in preterms babies. There may be an elevated direct (or conjugated) bilirubin level. Jaundice visible on the palms and soles, unresponsiveness to phototherapy, and a rapid rise in bilirubin levels during phototherapy indicate pathological jaundice.

Phototherapy is initiated in babies with pathological jaundice when the bilirubin levels exceed the 95th percentile on the total serum bilirubin (TSB) normogram. Babies are kept at a distance of 30-45 cm from the UV lamp (460-490 nm) with eyes and gonads covered. It is avoided in babies with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia due to the risk of bronze-baby syndrome. Dehydration and hypocalcemia are potential complications and breastfeeding is encouraged.

Exchange transfusion (ET) is done in cases of bilirubin encephalopathy, Rh incompatibility with significant hemolysis, and bilirubin values exceeding TSB cutoffs for ET.

questions.text:
A 50 year old man presents to you with intense pruritus, yellowing of the abdomen, palms, soles and sclera. One year ago, the patient received a liver transplant due to a diagnosis of hepatocellular cancer. Lab reports are shown below. Biopsy performed is as follows. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Total Bilirubin - 30mg/dl

Direct Bilirubin - 26mg/dl

Alkaline Phosphatase(ALP) - 450 U/L

GGT - 20 U/L

AST - 25U/L

ALT - 35U/L
questions.solution:
This patient exhibiting a cholestatic pattern of jaundice, accompanied by ductopenia as observed in the biopsy, and having undergone a liver transplant one year ago, may be diagnosed with vanishing bile duct syndrome.

Chronic rejection is characterized by the presence of focal parenchymal necrosis, mononuclear cell infiltration, progressive cholestasis, and fibrosis. In some patients, this process will lead to the loss of intrahepatic bile ducts, which is called vanishing bile duct syndrome. 

Vanishing Bile Duct Syndrome (VBDS) is used to describe a clinicopathological condition characterized by the presence of cholestasis, which is the impairment of bile flow, together with the disappearance of intrahepatic bile ducts, also known as ductopenia. Various factors, such as immune processes, infections, medications, and ischaemia, have been implicated as potential causes of bile duct degeneration. This degradation might manifest within a relatively short period of a few months or progress gradually over an extended period of several years. In this regard, the medical practitioner has the ability to differentiate between an acute or subacute form that progresses over several months. In this form, the presence of ductular reaction and portal fibrosis is not easily noticeable, and the characteristics of acute cholestasis, rather than chronic cholestasis, are more prominent. This can be observed in cases such as ductopenia occurring in allograft rejection, severe graft-versus-host disease (GVHD), certain medications, and treated Hodgkin lymphoma.

Chronic transplant rejection typically presents itself following a period of several months to years. This process elicits a response from both the cellular and humoral components of the immune system(Type II and type IV hypersensitivity reactions). The CD4+ T cells exhibit a response to the recipient antigen-presenting cells (APCs) that present peptides derived from the donor, which may include the allogeneic major histocompatibility complex (MHC). The recipient T cells elicit a response and secrete cytokines, resulting in the proliferation of vascular smooth muscle, parenchymal atrophy, and interstitial fibrosis. It manifests as development of bronchiolitis obliterans in the pulmonary system, accelerated atherosclerosis in the cardiovascular system, graft nephropathy in the renal system, and vanishing bile duct syndrome in the hepatic system.

Other options

 Option A: Primary sclerosing cholangitis presents with fatigue, pruritus, and steatorrhea similar to PBC. It is more common in men in the 3-5th decade. It is characterized by diffuse inflammation and fibrosis of intra and extrahepatic ducts. The perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (p-ANCA), is positive and anti-mitochondrial antibodies is negative. Liver biopsy shows concentric "onion-skin" fibrosis. 

Option B: Autoimmune hepatitis (AIH) is characterised by extensive inflammation, fibrosis and ultimately cirrhosis. Pathological features include emperipolesis, interface hepatitis or piecemeal necrosis and rosette formation due to necrosis of groups of hepatocytes and resultant regeneration.

Option D: Biopsy of the specimen shows ductopenia and mononuclear cell infiltration. Laboratory reports also suggest a cholestatic pattern of jaundice, thus making the diagnosis of a recurrence of hepatocellular carcinoma less likely.

questions.text: A 2-month-old baby is brought with complaints of lethargy and reduced feeding. Clinical examination reveals yellowing of sclera, hypotonia and an enlarged tongue. Head circumference is at 90th percentile and weight is at 80th percentile. Abdomen is distended with a reducible mass at the umbilicus. Which of the following must be done to best manage this patient?
questions.solution:
A history of constipation, lethargy, reduced feeding, jaundice, and hypotonia is suggestive of primary hypothyroidism. Since the child is 2 months of age, this is a case of congenital hypothyroidism. The best way to manage these patients would be the administration of thyroid hormone supplements.

Causes of Congenital hypothyroidism:

         Goitrous

    (Palpable goiter)

     Non-goitrous

   (No palpable goiter)
  • Thyroid dyshormonogenesis
  • Iodine deficiency
  • Placental passage of antithyroid drugs
  • Thyroid dysgenesis
  • Thyroid receptor blocking antibodies
  • Central hypothyroidism

Clinical features of congenital hypothyroidism:

  • Prolongation of physiologic hyperbilirubinemia: early sign (it is due to delayed maturation of glucuronide conjugation)
  • Constipation: usually does not respond to treatment
  • Wide open anterior and posterior fontanelles (>0.5 cm) and cranial sutures
  • Developmental delay, delayed bone growth, delayed dentition
  • Cardiovascular: slow pulse rate, cardiomegaly, asymptomatic pericardial effusion, edema
  • Respiratory: macroglossia, feeding difficulties, choking spells, respiratory difficulties
  • Hematological: macrocytic anemia refractory to treatment with haematinics
  • Nervous system: hypothermia, hypotonia, slow relaxation of deep tendon reflexes, sluggishness, and somnolence.

Laboratory Findings:

Condition Goitre T4 TSH
Thyroid dysgenesis Absent Low Elevated
Thyroid dyshormonogenesis Present Low Elevated
Thyroid receptor blocking antibodies Absent Low Elevated
Central hypothyroidism Absent Low Normal/Low

Other options 

Option B: Pyrimethamine + Leucovorin is used in the management of congenital toxoplasmosis. Congenital toxoplasmosis can also present with neonatal jaundice alongwith with an increased head circumference (as seen in this patient), and abdominal distension. But, umbilical hernia as well as macroglossia points towards a diagnosis of congenital hypothyroidism instead.

Option C: Kasai's procedure ( Hepatoportoenterostomy ) is performed in the management of biliary atresia. Biliary atresia is characterized by the manifestation of newborn jaundice, which tends to occur with greater frequency following the first two weeks of an infant's life. The presence of hypotonia and an enlarged head in this patient does not contribute to the diagnosis of biliary atresia.

Option D: Diazoxide, umbilical hernia repair and tongue reduction surgery can be performed in patients with a diagnosis of Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome. Patients with Beckwith-Wiedmann syndrome manifest with enlarged tongue, abdominal distension as well as umbilical hernia. However, it is important to note that these patients do not have scleral icterus characteristically as a presenting feature.

questions.text: An 8-day-old neonate presents with yellowish discolouration of skin and sclera. Which of the following may not be a cause of neonatal jaundice that appears after the first week of life?
questions.solution:
Erythroblastosis fetalis causes neonatal jaundice and manifests within the first 24 hours of life, not after 1st week.

Jaundice in the first 24 hours of life requires immediate attention and can be due to erythroblastosis fetalis, concealed hemorrhage, sepsis, or congenital infections, including syphilis, cytomegalovirus, rubella, and toxoplasmosis. Jaundice appearing on the 2nd or 3rd day of life is usually physiologic but also can be due to early onset breastfeeding jaundice and Crigler-Najjar syndrome (familial non-hemolytic icterus). Neonatal jaundice appearing after the 3rd day but within the 1st week of life can be due to bacterial sepsis, urinary tract infections or other infections like syphilis, etc.

Neonatal jaundice appearing after the 1st week of life can be due a number of conditions like breast milk jaundice, congenital atresia or paucity of bile ducts, hepatitis, cystic fibrosis, hemolytic anemia, enzyme deficiencies etc.

Physiological jaundice/Icterus neonatorum is due to increased bilirubin production from the breakdown of fetal red blood cells combined with transient limitation in the conjugation of bilirubin by the immature neonatal liver. Continuation of breastfeeding exclusively resolves most of the cases.

questions.text: A middle-aged man with chronic alcohol consumption presents with yellowish discoloration of the skin, abdominal pain, and fever. Which of the following medicines is most likely to reduce the mortality in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of alcoholic liver disease. Oral prednisolone for 4 weeks helps in reducing mortality levels.

Oral prednisolone is given at a dose of 40 mg orally daily for 4 weeks and then slowly tapered off. For patients unable to take oral medications, methylprednisolone, 32 mg per day IV, is used. The combination of glucocorticoids with N-acetylcysteine infusion might add short-term survival benefit at 1 month. Long-term prognosis in patients (>1 year) largely depends on alcohol abstinence and underlying cirrhosis. Liver transplantation should be considered in patients not responding to glucocorticoids.

Octreotide, a somatostatin analogue, is used in the treatment of esophageal varices in patients with alcoholic liver disease and is not prescribed to reduce mortality.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old male had yellowish eyes, dark urine, body itching, and clay-colored feces. He had three similar instances over three years, interspersed with asymptomatic periods. USG shows a normal gall bladder with no calculi. Normal intrahepatic, extrahepatic biliary tree and pancreatic ductal system on MRCP. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Total Bilirubin - 30mg/dl

Direct Bilirubin - 26mg/dl

Alkaline Phosphatase(ALP) - 450 U/L

GGT - 20 U/L

AST - 25U/L

ALT - 35U/L
questions.solution:
The individual presenting with clinical manifestations indicative of obstructive jaundice resulting from intrahepatic cholestasis and intermittent periods of asymptomatic episodes between cholestasis episodes aligns with a diagnosis of Benign Recurrent Intrahepatic Cholestasis (BRIC).

Patients with Benign Recurrent Intrahepatic Cholestasis (BRIC) have symptoms of intrahepatic cholestasis ranging from weeks to months and asymptomatic episodes in between. A diagnosis is usually made once other causes of obstructive jaundice have been ruled out such as common bile duct stones, cystic duct stones, pancreatic strictures, etc. It can be differentiated from Progressive familial intrahepatic cholestasis(Option D) due to the presence of progressive hyperbilirubinemia which begins in infancy and progresses gradually to liver failure and is caused due to mutations in bile salt excretory protein (BSEP).

Benign Recurrent Intrahepatic Cholestasis follows an autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance. It is distinguished by recurring bouts of cholestatic jaundice that can persist for several weeks or months. It typically manifests throughout the period of adolescence. Prodromal symptoms include itching, nausea, vomiting, and weight loss. Patients have no symptoms during the intervals between bouts. Blood tests commonly indicate the presence of conjugated hyperbilirubinemia accompanied by increased levels of alkaline phosphatase. Cholangiography reveals no evidence of biliary blockage. The liver biopsy reveals the presence of cholestasis during episodes while returning to a normal state between episodes.
The BRIC condition is linked to genetic mutations in two bile acid transporters, namely ATP8B1 (also known as BRIC1) which encodes FIC1, and ABCB11 (also known as BRIC2) which encodes the bile salt export pump (BSEP). A combination of rifampin, cholestyramine and prednisone has been tried, leading to reduced episodes. The prognosis of this condition is good.

Dubin-Johnson syndrome, Rotor syndrome, and Byler disease are disorders of bilirubin metabolism which lead to predominantly conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

Mixed or predominantly conjugated hyperbilirubinemia occurs either due to impaired excretion of conjugated bilirubin into the bile ductules or backward leakage of the bile. 

Familial defects in hepatic excretory function include:

  • Dubin-Johnson syndrome
  • Rotor syndrome
  • Benign recurrent intrahepatic cholestasis (BRIC)
  • Progressive familial intrahepatic cholestasis (FIC)
    • Type 1 - is called Byler disease

Note: Byler disease is a cholestatic disease that presents episodically from infancy. It is due to FIC1 mutation and it can lead to malnutrition, growth retardation, and end stage liver disease during childhood.

Other options 

Option A: Rotor syndrome(RS) is an autosomal recessive disease characterized by non-hemolytic jaundice due to deficiency in OATP1B1 and OATP1B3 transporters in the hepatocytes. This phenomenon results from impaired hepatocellular storage of conjugated bilirubin that leaks into plasma, causing hyperbilirubinemia. Patients with Rotor syndrome do not have asymptomatic episodes in between with elevated ALP.

Option C: Dubin–Johnson syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder with predominantly conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, due to a mutation in the MRP- 2 protein. Liver biopsy shows characteristic black-coloured pigment deposition in the centrilobular hepatocytes' lysosomes. Patients with dubin johnsons syndrome do not have asymptomatic episodes in between with elevated ALP.

questions.text: A woman at 34 weeks of gestation presents with severe pruritus and yellowish discoloration of the sclera. Her total bilirubin level was 3.8 mg/dL and serum transaminase levels were mildly elevated. A biopsy of the liver would most likely show?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy which is caused due to defective transport of bilirubin from the hepatocytes into the biliary canaliculi as depicted in the third histopathological slide.  Liver biopsy shows mild cholestasis with bile plugs in the hepatocytes and canaliculi of the centrilobular region.

Intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy is a reversible cholestatic disease that may occur later in pregnancy. It is characterized by intense pruritus, which is worse on palms and soles, and icterus. The key laboratory findings include increased serum bile acid levels, elevated transaminases, and elevated direct and total bilirubin serum concentrations.

Management:

  • Antihistamines and topical emollients
  • Cholestyramine
  • Ursodeoxycholic acid

Ursodeoxycholic acid is the drug of choice in obstetric cholestasis. Cholestyramine causes decreased absorption of fat-soluble vitamins, which leads to vitamin K deficiency. Fetal coagulopathy may develop, which may lead to intracranial haemorrhage and stillbirth, and therefore it is not preferred.

Other slides:

Slide 1: Autoimmune hepatitis (AIH) is characterised by extensive inflammation, fibrosis and ultimately cirrhosis. Pathological features include emperipolesis, interface hepatitis or piecemeal necrosis and rosette formation due to necrosis of groups of hepatocytes and resultant regeneration. Below is a histology slide depicting the same.

Slide 2: Hepatoblastoma is the most common childhood liver tumor. Histologically it is composed of small polygonal embryonal cells forming trabeculae, acini, or papillary structures in the developing liver.

Image below: Histology of hepatoblastoma showing proliferating hepatoblasts consisting of round epithelial type cells.

Slide 4: Fatty change is mostly seen in the liver because it is the major organ involved in fat metabolism; however, it may also occur in the heart, muscles, and kidneys. The below image shows hepatic macro-vesicular steatosis (fatty change) along with intraparenchymal cholestasis . The lipid accumulates in the hepatocytes as vacuoles. These vacuoles have a clear appearance on H&E staining.

questions.text: A 60 year old patient comes to the emergency department with complaints of yellowing of his eyes, abdominal pain and vomiting. Physical examination reveals the presence of jugular venous distension and hepatomegaly. He goes on to say 4 days back he had severe chest pain which self-resolved. The pathophysiological process behind the development of jaundice in this patient may also be observed in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
This patient has jaundice due to ischemic hepatitis following an episode of myocardial infarction a few days back which leads to low blood pressure. Formation of portosystemic shunts also leads to low blood pressure in cases of chronic liver cirrhosis leading to hepatorenal syndrome.  

Increased bilirubin production Impaired bilirubin conjugation Impaired hepatic bilirubin uptake
 		 Extrahepatic cholestasis

Hemolysis

Gilbert syndrome 

Crigler-Najjar syndrome(Option C)

 Heart Failure

Common bile duct stone 
Dyserythropoiesis Sepsis  Portosystemic shunts Benign stricture 
Extravasation of blood into tissues (Option B) Hyperthyroidism Fasting Benign polyp 
    Rifampin, Probenicid, Gemfibrozil Primary sclerosing cholangitis (Option D)

Ischemic hepatitis, known by different terms such as ischemic hepatopathy, hypoxic hepatitis, shock liver, or acute cardiogenic liver injury, has a prevalence of 2.5% among patients admitted to an intensive care unit. This condition arises from a sudden decrease in cardiac output caused by acute myocardial infarction, arrhythmia, or septic or hemorrhagic shock. Typically, it occurs in patients with passive congestion of the liver.  The presence or observation of clinical hypotension may be lacking or not documented. In some cases, the triggering event is arterial hypoxemia related to respiratory failure, sleep apnea, severe anaemia, heat stroke, carbon monoxide poisoning, cocaine usage, or bacterial endocarditis. The occurrence of many precipitants is frequently observed. Administration of statin medication before hospital admission has the potential to confer protection against the occurrence of ischemic hepatitis.

 Elevations in blood alkaline phosphatase and bilirubin levels are typically of a modest nature; nevertheless, the presence of jaundice is indicative of more unfavourable outcomes. The prolongation of prothrombin time may lead to the development of encephalopathy or hepatopulmonary syndrome. The mortality rate associated with the underlying disease is notably elevated, especially among patients undergoing vasopressor therapy or experiencing septic shock, acute kidney disease, or coagulopathy. However, in patients who successfully recover, the levels of aminotransferase return to their normal state rapidly, typically within a week, which stands in contrast to the prolonged normalization period observed in cases of viral hepatitis.

questions.text: A 2-week-old baby presented with yellowish discoloration of the skin. Investigations revealed markedly elevated direct bilirubin levels. Which of the following conditions should be suspected in the newborn?
questions.solution:
The raised direct bilirubin levels indicate conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Among the given options, biliary atresia causes conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

Biliary atresia is a disorder characterised by destruction or absence of bile ducts in a newborn. It leads to obstruction to the flow of bile thereby causing leaking of conjugated bilirubin into the circulation.

Option B: Physiological jaundice of the newborn occurs due to immaturity of the newborn's liver.  It is not able to conjugate the excess bilirubin produced after birth. It leads to unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

Option C: Breast milk may contain certain factors that inhibit the conjugation of bilirubin leading to unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

Option D: Hemolytic disease of the newborn causes excess production of bilirubin due to hemolysis leading to unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient presents with the following finding as shown in the image below. On further investigation, she is found to have reduced levels of the enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase. The discolouration of the sclera is attributed to the affinity of bilirubin towards ______.
questions.solution:
With the given clinical scenario and with reduced levels of enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase, the patient is most likely suffering from Gilbert syndrome. Scleral discolouration in patients with jaundice is due to the increased affinity of bilirubin to elastin. 

The high elastin concentration in sclerae results in a specific attraction to bilirubin, and the observation of scleral icterus suggests a minimum serum bilirubin level of 3 mg/dL. The identification of scleral icterus is much more challenging in the presence of fluorescent lighting within the examination room. In the event that the examiner has reason to suspect the presence of scleral icterus, an additional area that should be assessed is the sublingual region. 

Gilbert syndrome is an autosomal recessive condition characterized by decreased activity of the enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase, which is responsible for the conjugation of bilirubin. This leads to unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, which presents as yellowish discolouration of the sclera (icterus/jaundice) as seen in the given image.

Individuals with Gilbert syndrome are usually asymptomatic except for intermittent episodes of jaundice, which usually occurs for the first time during adolescence, due to changes in the concentration of sex hormones. Some patients may have complaints like malaise, fatigue, nausea, anxiety, loss of appetite, and abdominal discomfort. Symptoms are usually precipitated by triggers such as fasting, intercurrent illness, menstruation, and dehydration.

Administration of phenobarbital shows normalisation of the serum bilirubin concentration and hepatic bilirubin clearance.

Gilbert syndrome usually doesn't require any treatment.

questions.text: A 5-day-old alert neonate is brought by his mother because of concerns about inadequate consumption of breast milk. He passes stools frequently, the previous stool was dark green in color. He wet 2 diapers on day 4 of life. Total bilirubin is 15mg/dl and direct bilirubin is 0.4mg/dl. Which of the following is the most probable cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with increased indirect bilirubin during the first week of life and subtle signs of dehydration like reduced urine output (2 diapers on day 4) is highly suggestive of a diagnosis of Breastfeeding jaundice. 

Breastfeeding jaundice commonly presents within the first week of life due to inadequate feeds due to improper latch technique among other risk factors. This reduced consumption ensues into reduced elimination via stool and therefore increased enterohepatic circulation of indirect bilirubin. Signs of dehydration such as reduced urine output which is normally equal to the neonatal age in days( ie, 3 diapers on day 3), while this patient just had 2 wet diapers on day 4 thus necessitating attention. 

Type of Jaundice Breastfeeding jaundice Breast milk jaundice
Onset Early-onset
1st week after birth (usually appears after 24 - 72 hours of birth)		 Late-onset
after the 7th day with maximal concentrations as high as 10–30 mg/dl reached during the 2nd-3rd week.
Pathophysiology decreased milk intake with dehydration and/or reduced caloric intake. presence of glucuronidase in breast milk 
Management Continue breastfeeding and supplementation with formula feeds if needed Continue breastfeeding and the bilirubin gradually decreases but may persist for 3-10 weeks at lower levels; phototherapy may be of benefit in some cases.

 

Other options: 

Option A: Biliary atresia causes conjugated hyperbilirubinemia in infants aged 2-8 weeks. Patients with biliary atresia typically exhibit acholic stools, dark urine, and an enlarged liver and not dark green stools as seen in this patient.

Option C: Dubin-Johnson syndrome is also a cause of conjugated hyperbilirubinemia with an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern.

questions.text: Which of the following is the earliest sign of recovery in a patient with obstructive jaundice?
questions.solution:
The earliest sign of recovery in patients with obstructive jaundice is the reappearance of urobilinogen in the urine.

Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia refers to the increase in direct bilirubin levels. It usually occurs due to impaired excretion of bilirubin due to obstructive biliary pathology. The diagnosis can be made by elevation of serum direct bilirubin levels, hepatic enzymes (Alkaline phosphatase specifically raised in cholestasis), and absent urinary urobilinogen. Obstruction of biliary ducts may be intrahepatic or extrahepatic and can be localised by imaging techniques.  

Bilirubin is the breakdown product of heme metabolism which is formed in the reticuloendothelial cells of the liver. It is insoluble in water and is known as unconjugated (indirect) bilirubin. It is transported to the liver after binding to albumin, where it undergoes conjugation with glucuronic acid. The final product is known as conjugated bilirubin (direct bilirubin) which drains into the duodenum. On reaching the colon, the unconjugated form is acted upon by bacterial beta glucuronidases and reduced into colorless urobilinogen. Almost 90% is excreted through feces as stercobilinogen, and the remaining will undergo enterohepatic cycling. A small fraction of this escapes hepatic uptake and will be excreted in the urine as urobilinogen.

Normally, urine bilirubin is absent. However, in obstructive jaundice, bilirubin cannot drain to the intestine to be converted into urobilinogen. Thus, fecal urobilinogen is absent, which gives the characteristic clay-colored stools. The presence of urine bilirubin is an indication of post-hepatic obstruction and presents as cola/dark-colored urine. Increase bilirubin deposition in the skin, resulting in yellowish discoloration and may lead to pruritus.

questions.text:
An adult male patient presents with yellow discolouration of the sclera. There was a history of recurrent mild jaundice since childhood. His lab values are mentioned below. A liver biopsy was performed which revealed normal liver architecture with coarse granular black pigmentation. The mutation of which protein is involved in the following condition?

AST: 20 U/L , ALT: 18 U/L

Total bilirubin : 4.2mg/dl, Conjugated bilirubin: 3.6 mg/dl

Total protein: 6.4 g/dL, normal A/G ratio.

Urine: Normal porphyrin levels.
questions.solution:
Yellow discolouration of the sclera with coarse granular black pigmentation of the liver is suggestive of Dubin–Johnson syndrome, characterized by a mutation in the MRP-2 protein.

Dubin–Johnson syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder with predominantly conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. It is due to a defect in the active transport of bilirubin across the canalicular membrane, due to a mutation in the MRP-2 protein. It is also known as black liver jaundice due to the accumulation of a dark pigment, derived from epinephrine metabolites, in the lysosomes of centrilobular hepatocytes. Bromosulpthalein test on plasma shows 2 peaks.

Option A: OATP1B1 and OATP1B3 are mutated in Rotor syndrome. It is due to defective bilirubin excretion and causes conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

Option B: BSEP protein is mutated in progressive familial intrahepatic cholestasis (PFIC type-2) and benign recurrent intrahepatic cholestasis (BRIC-2).

Option C: MRP-3 is mutated in PFIC type-3.

A patient came to you with symptoms of nausea, vomiting, fever and yellowing of his eyes. 6 days back he had symptoms of TB for which HRZE was started. Laboratory results are as follows. Which of the following represents the mechanism by which this rifampin has caused liver injury?
Total serum bilirubin  10 mg/dL
Serum direct bilirubin 2 mg/dL
Serum indirect bilirubin 8 mg/dL
Hemoglobin  12 g/dL

questions.solution:
This patient's symptoms of yellowing of eyes, fever and vomiting coupled with laboratory results showing predominantly increased indirect bilirubin is seen in patients with Rifampin-induced hepatitis. Rifampin impairs the bilirubin uptake and thus causes unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. 

Rifampin-induced jaundice is most commonly seen within 1 week of initiation of treatment and once other causes of hemolysis have been excluded reinitiation of the drug must be done so as to complete the regimen. Elevated bilirubin production may potentially arise as a result of hemolysis induced by antitubercular medication; however, the absence of abnormal hemoglobin and lactate dehydrogenase levels excludes this as a potential aetiology for unconjugated bilirubinemia in the present case.

questions.text: An elderly gentleman presents with weight loss, the passage of dark-colored urine, and pale putty stools. On examination, you note a yellowish discoloration of the skin. Which of the following is likely to be elevated in the serum?
questions.solution:
This case scenario is suggestive of obstructive jaundice in which conjugated bilirubin levels in the serum will be elevated.

Yellowish discolouration of the skin (jaundice), weight loss, dark-coloured urine (bilirubinuria), and pale stools are all indicative of obstructive jaundice.

Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia refers to the increase in serum conjugated or direct bilirubin levels. It usually occurs due to impaired excretion of bilirubin due to obstructive biliary pathology or hereditary syndromes. The diagnosis can be made by elevation of serum direct bilirubin levels, hepatic enzymes (Alkaline phosphatase specifically raised in cholestasis) and absent urinary urobilinogen. Obstruction of biliary ducts may be intrahepatic or extrahepatic and can be localised by imaging techniques.  

Bilirubin is the breakdown product of heme metabolism which is formed in the reticuloendothelial cells of the liver. It is insoluble in water and is known as unconjugated (indirect) bilirubin. It is transported to the liver after binding to albumin, where it undergoes conjugation with glucuronic acid. The final product is known as conjugated bilirubin (direct bilirubin) which drains into the duodenum. On reaching the colon, the unconjugated form is acted upon by bacterial beta glucuronidases and reduced into colorless urobilinogen. Almost 90% is excreted through faeces as stercobilinogen, and the remaining will undergo enterohepatic cycling. A small fraction of this escapes hepatic uptake and will be excreted in the urine as urobilinogen.

Normally, urine bilirubin is absent. However, in obstructive jaundice, bilirubin cannot drain to the intestine to be converted into urobilinogen. Thus, fecal urobilinogen becomes absent, which gives the characteristic steatorrhea. The presence of urine bilirubin is an indication of post-hepatic obstruction and presents as cola/dark-colored urine. Increase bilirubin deposition in the skin, resulting in yellowish discoloration and may lead to pruritus.

Serum bilirubin can be measured using the van den Bergh reaction. The bilirubin is exposed to diazotized sulfanilic acid with/without alcohol and total and direct bilirubin levels are measured respectively. Indirect bilirubin levels would be the difference between the two values.

questions.text: A 3.3 Kg term neonate is admitted on day 3 of life with yellowish discoloration of the skin and is going to undergo phototherapy. What is the most effective wavelength of light used for treatment?
questions.solution:
The most effective range of wavelength of light for phototherapy in neonatal indirect hyperbilirubinemia is 460–490 nm (blue-green light).

Clinical jaundice and indirect hyperbilirubinemia are reduced by exposure to the high intensity of light in the visible spectrum by 3 mechanisms:

  • Irreversible structural isomerization: Most important mechanism; acts by forming lumirubin from native bilirubin. It is then excreted by the kidneys in the unconjugated state.
  • Reversible photo-isomerization reaction: converts toxic unconjugated bilirubin into an unconjugated configurational isomer. It is then excreted in bile without conjugation.
  • Photo-oxidation: minor method

 

Blue-green light (460 to 490 nm) is more effective than blue light (430 to 470 nm) due to the following reasons:

  • Blue-green light preferentially favors the formation of lumirubin
  • Its longer wavelength (460 to 490 nm) enhances skin penetration
  • Pure blue light can mask cyanosis in an infant

Note:

Phototherapy is effective only when bilirubin is accumulated in the skin. There is no role of prophylactic phototherapy in mild/ sub-clinical jaundice. 

Contraindication of phototherapy: Porphyria.

questions.text: A 23-year-old food blogger presents with complaints of icterus and abdominal fullness. She returned yesterday from a vacation in Egypt where she tried fava beans. Her peripheral smear is given below. Which of the following drugs is not contraindicated in her condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and blood film showing bite cells (arrows) is suggestive of glucose 6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency. Ceftriaxone is not contraindicated in G6PD deficiency.

G6PD is an enzyme in the hexose monophosphate pathway (HMP) that maintains the cellular levels of NADPH. NADPH then provides reducing equivalents needed for the conversion of oxidized glutathione to reduced glutathione. This reduced glutathione acts as a cofactor in reactions that neutralize compounds such as H2O2, thereby protecting against oxidant injury.  

Thus, G6PD deficiency causes acute hemolysis in conditions of high oxidative stress that are triggered by:

  • infections
  • fava beans (a staple in Egyptian cuisine)
  • certain drugs

Oxidative damage to RBCs leads to crosslinking of reactive sulfhydryl groups on globin chains, which then becomes denatured and form membrane-bound precipitates called Heinz bodies. When these cells on pass through spleen, heinz bodies are plucked by macrophages, giving bite cells.

Clinically, most patients are asymptomatic. When exposed to the triggers, patient develops:

  • Episodic hemolysis, both intravascular and extravascular
  • Hemolytic anaemia
  • Hemoglobinemia
  • Hemoglobinuria

G6PD deficiency is an X-linked recessive (XLR) disorder which is the most common cause of congenital hemolytic anemia due to enzyme deficiency.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old boy presented with yellowish discolouration of the skin and sclerae for the last 3 days. He is otherwise asymptomatic. He had a viral fever one week ago which has now resolved. His investigations are shown below. The dysfunctional enzyme resides in which of the following sites?

Serum bilirubin: 2.4 mg/dL
Unconjugated bilirubin: 2.1mg/dL
Conjugated bilirubin: 0.3mg/dL
Serum AST and ALT: Normal
questions.solution:
This patient has a short history of jaundice, which appeared only during a period of stress (viral fever). The lab reports show increased unconjugated bilirubin (normal 0.2-0.8 mg/dL) and normal AST and ALT levels. All this points toward a diagnosis of Gilbert syndrome. The dysfunctional enzyme ie UDP-glucuronyltransferase is present within the smooth endoplasmic reticulum.

Gilbert syndrome is a benign, familial disorder characterized by mild intermittent jaundice usually seen during stress, fatigue, or alcohol use. The condition is recognized to arise from a mutation in the promoter region of the UGT1A1 gene, which results in mildly decreased UDP-glucuronyltransferase production. This causes a reduction in the liver's ability to conjugate bilirubin, thus causing unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. The total bilirubin value is usually < 3 mg/dL. 

Other options:

Option A: Rough endoplasmic reticulum helps in protein synthesis which encompasses various processes, such as post-translational modifications, folding, and sorting. The process of translation occurs in the rough endoplasmic reticulum (RER), where ribosomes that are connected to the membrane are responsible for synthesizing polypeptides. This synthesis involves the translation of mature mRNA transcripts into amino acids, which are subsequently joined to form polypeptide chains.

Option B: Golgi bodies (or Golgi apparatus) appear as stacks of flattened membranous cisternae surrounded by clusters of vesicles. It is responsible for the additional processing and sorting of proteins obtained from the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) in order to facilitate their transportation to their respective destinations, which include lysosomes, the plasma membrane, or secretion. Furthermore, it should be emphasized that the synthesis of glycolipids and sphingomyelin takes place within the Golgi apparatus.

Option D: Lysosomes are organelles contained by a membrane, housing a diverse range of enzymes with the ability to degrade many biological polymers, including proteins, nucleic acids, carbohydrates, and lipids. Lysosomes serve as the cellular digestive system, responsible for the degradation of extracellular material and the digestion of obsolete intracellular components with the help of hydrolases. Mutations in the genes encoding these enzymes lead to lysosomal storage diseases.

questions.text: A 20-year-old model has presented to you with complaints of abdominal pain, vomiting, and yellowing palms and soles. She also says she wants to compete in Miss Universe on a spinach-carrot diet. Which finding helps distinguish this patient from jaundice?
questions.solution:
This patient who has been consuming an excess amount of carotene is suffering from Carotenemia. The absence of yellowing of the sclera helps distinguish this condition from a patient with jaundice. Other symptoms are common among those patients with jaundice as well as carotenemia.

Hypercarotenemia is a condition that is linked to elevated consumption of foods that are rich in carotene, such as pumpkin, carrots, spinach, lettuce, tomatoes, and mangoes.  Additionally, hypercarotenemia has been observed to exhibit associations with several medical disorders, including hypopituitarism, hypothyroidism, inborn errors of metabolism, as well as liver and kidney illness. The incidence of hypercarotenemia is generally unaffected by demographic factors such as age and gender, however it is more commonly observed in the pediatric population, particularly among newborns and young children.The presence of hypercalcemia in newborns and children is typically accompanied by the observation of a yellowish colouring on the palms and soles, which arises from the accumulation of carotenoids within adipose tissue. It is imperative to differentiate hypercarotenemia from jaundice due to the absence of scleral involvement in the former condition.

Typically, a thorough history and comprehensive physical examination are deemed adequate in the process of narrowing down distinctions, rendering laboratory tests largely unnecessary for diagnosing carotenemia associated with dietary factors. higher levels of serum carotene are typically observed through laboratory testing, with values ranging from 250 to 500 micrograms per deciliter. Concurrently, liver enzymes tend to exhibit normal or slightly higher levels. The quantification of carotenoid antioxidants in human skin in vivo can be achieved by the utilization of resonant Raman spectroscopy and reflectance spectroscopy, both of which are non-invasive optical techniques. These methods enable the measurement of skin carotene levels.

The fundamental approach to treatment involves the reduction of carotene intake in the diet. The reduction of carotene consumption is expected to result in the eventual resolution of skin pigmentation and other symptoms.
